reviewText:
Early Access Review

EDIT: I just can't recommend the game right now due to the lack of players. When the playercount increases to the point where you can fairly easily get into a game with people at similar skill levels to you I'll remove this edit. Just bear in mind the low playercount if you're considering buying the game.

Innovative, addictive and incredibly satisfying. Whether you have played for 1 hour or 1,000 hours the awesome feeling you get from being a part of epic plays never fades. The game is quite unpolished but if you can see through the clunky UI and lacking features there is a great game beneath. As with a lot of Early Access games, it's a diamond in the rough.

Supraball in comparison to Rocket League:   Deathball..." (the predecessor of Supraball) "... was one of the main reasons why Rocket League exists" - Psyonix Adam on Reddit
I expect this comparison is what a lot of people will be wanting to know. I'll preface this section by saying I have about 650 ingame hours in Rocket League and about 2
date: 000 in Supraball.  Rocket League gave me a very similar feeling of excitement that I got from Supraball when I first started playing.  Deep down at their core they are essentially the same game - put the ball in the goal
recommended: just with different methods of doing so. Both are very pure
hoursPlayed: simple games which give you some basic controls and then set you free to do what you wish.\nI feel like Supraball gives you a lot more ways to be creative  and play the game though to the degree that every second of the game you are holding the ball the tree of your choices branches 100 times: will you do a little rollspin to juke a defender
voteText: will you pass to a teammate who is boosted and flying across the map for a volley combo
helpfulPercent: will you panic and do a horrible pass back to your keeper and score a hilarious own goal or will you do the countless other things available to you?  More complex plays are also far more accessible in Supraball
votesHelpful: within 100 hours of play you can be setting up strong charge to volley goals to score 300km/h screamer goals
votesTotal: whereas in Rocket League setting up a pass play like this is far
votesFunny:
far more difficult.  The autolock pass also makes passing very easy and allows new players to perform teamplay quite easily.  Now let's move onto the pro's and con's of Supraball in it's Early Access State.


Pros: +++  Every match plays differently.  There are so many different ways to play that you never end up playing the same game twice. It has the "just 1 more match" feeling and so can be very addictive and has huge replayability.
+++  4 unique positions to play: Goalkeeper
column16: Midfielder and Striker.  You can sink thousands of hours into a position and still have room to learn and innovate. Or
column18: you're free to play however you want!\n++  The skill ceiling is disgustingly high
column19: I have sunk probably 2000 hours into goalkeeping in the Alpha/Beta and I'm not even close to the skill cap. The skill floor is pretty high too
column20: but even when you first start playing and have no idea what you're doing it is still really enjoyable\n++ Applying curves and combinations of curves to your shots gives huge variety to the gameplay and  lots of opportunities for creative
column21:
unique and flashy plays
+  Intuitive and fairly simple controls  similar to most FPS games
+  There's something for everyone . Public matches are more casual and relaxed and ranked is more serious. It's enjoyable to play even if you typically don't like sports games like myself.
+ Multiple varients of the 3v3 and 5v5 maps (similar to Rocket League) with different visual styles
+ Even if this game does not do too well and has a small playerbase (eg. 50 to 100 players) it can still be fun. The whole time I have played from 0 to 2000 hours there has probably been an average of 40 players online and even so it is a blast.

Ehhh: ~Only 2 game modes (3v3 and 5v5) though both gamemodes focus on very different ways of playing
~ Curved shots bouncing off of walls are unintuitive but add a huge amount of depth to the game  that allows crazy solo wall jukes and is why the striker position is viable

Cons: ---  A clunky UI and missing lots of useful features such as easily partying with friends
column22: good matchmaking and team matchmaking (these features are planned).  The lobby system has matchmaking within it to balance teams but there is no way to easily queue and join a match like you can in Rocket League.\n--  For some people the optimisation is god awful even on a monster rig
column23: for others the game runs perfectly on a terrible computer.\n--  The price is based on the gameplay and potential of future content
column24: not the amount of content it has right now.  This game is priced similarly to Rocket League
column25: but doesn't have any of the extra features. You may want to hold off on purchasing until these features are added if they are important to you.\n-The devs "rely on the community renting the majority of servers"
column26: which is certainly not something I'm used to in my games and seems very strange to me\n- Despite what the steam store says  the game is fairly unpolished
column27: lacking a lot of nice little features like cosmetics or unlockables\n- Whilst the game can be played by ignoring your teammates
column28: utilising them properly is the best way to play. This might not appeal to some pure solo players\n-  Some bugs can affect the mid to high level of play
column29:
include random weird bounces off of walls and occasionally your shield not working. These are almost entirely unnoticeable in the first 100 hours of play though and will hopefully be patched

tl;dr: It's basically meth

Edit: The default controls can be a bit wonky
column30: I would advise changing the following:\n"Pass" to RMB
column33: "Quickshot" to Middle Mouse. "Shield" to RMB and the others whatever you feel comfortable with. If you want to goalkeep
column34: turn "double tap dash" off and set the "Dash Jump" key to something you feel comfortable with."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game HAD so much potential. Unfortunately it has been abandoned for a UE4 version that probably will never see the light of day. The game itself hasn't had any real updates in about 6 months or more. They worked on nothing but the launcher, which came out very confusing and poorly done. It's quite buggy, crashes a lot, sometimes buttons don't work and you have to restart, losing your spot in the process.

There is NO TUTORIAL, so new players quickly get frustrated and leave, never to be seen again. The game is largely dead already, a failed release brought us a 96 player peak on the following Sunday.  It's priced next to Rocket League with very little to offer in comparison. It's unfortunate because the gameplay itself is far more versatile and deep than Rocket League and the skill ceiling is very high, especially in a team capacity.  I personally offered to work on the tutorial, I have a great voice for these things, unfortunately the man in charge DavidM spent his time making maps that nobody likes instead of something the game truly needed, A TUTORIAL.  He decided to release it on the same weekend as OVERWATCH without even the tools for players to learn how to play.

It's truly sad watching this potentially great game get ruined by DavidM's unwillingness to listen to anybody, or even consider other's opinions.  Throughout the history of Deathball and Supraball it has been the same. Multiple helpers/coders have quit due to DavidM, I've heard first hand stories from multiple people who no longer can take DavidM's attitude and quit over it.  It's a shame that Marenz, who is the one who actually does most of the work won't take a more active/public role and make DavidM give him more power in what happens with the game. Honestly most of the mistakes are just completely uncalled for, such as releasing it on the same day as Overwatch with no tutorial, he even changed the default controls so old players have no reference to helping newer players.  The average child would agree that this was a huge mistake, but not DavidM, who told everybody he would get at least 700 players on launch day...well Steam charts is already showing a decline day by day, never reaching over 200 concurrent players at ANY time.

Streamers tried to play, couldn't find players to play with and gave up and went to play Rocket League, another blown opportunity. Let's give our dead game to a bunch of popular streamers so people can laugh at it when they can't actually play because it's DEAD.

I wish there was more time to get into specifics, all I can say is the game is worth $5 and until it's actually polished and completed they have no business putting themselves into Rocket League status.  The store page claims they've developed it since 2012 and it's a polished game".  Far from it
date: the gameplay itself is more or less complete (other than bugs they refuse to fix) but nothing about the experience is polished
recommended: at all.\n\nThe Project Leader DavidM has resorted to deleting reddit posts
voteText: deleting comments on the Steam forums and banning people from posting on Steam all because they gave the game a bad review. He's an immature person who has no business leading a professional project and he's just abusing his powers to try and hide the negative comments at this point."

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFollowing this game from 2014 I had high hopes for Supraball. The competitive nature of the game made it very fun but little has been added to the game from the 2 years I've been watching it. There is no match making system like my favourite mp games have. You simply can choose your opponents and team mates making the rank system irrelevant. There were plans to move the game over to Unreal 4 engine which the devs said would help them massively but that didn't happen as it would take too long" the devs said even after they said it would speed up development (this is most likely due to the success of Rocket League and a panic to release the game). The only thing added was a few average looking (the stadium is fantastic mind) maps
date:
a start up launcher (which is not great) and some small gameplay tweaks.

I'm not a fan of the art style which I honestly thought the stickmen were placeholders and the arena's seem rushed and uninspired.

The game still has potential like I thought 2 years ago but in the current state at the same price as Rocket League I recommend not buying this. The devs saw the success Rocket League had.. panicked and rushed the release of this and slapped a 'Early Access' title on it.

Plus the ranks have not been reset from the alpha which is quite unfair to new players. Don't be fooled by the hours of other reviewers too.. a lot of players sat in lobbies for hours at a time as a chat room."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Finding this gem of a game in the summer of 2014 was one the best decisions i've made. No game has given me more pleasure in competing and drived me to become the best player I can be for my team. I don't think there is another game with the same emphasis on teamplay that Supraball has. It's like soccer mixed with hockey but with cannon guns that can shoot the ball really fast. The graphics may be a turn off for some individuals but I hope that people can look past the cartoony looks as there is more to gameplay than just graphics. There are still a few bugs but that is why this is only the early access release and not the final release. I look forward to meeting the newer players and hopefully together we can make this game a competitive e-sport.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Wall of text! \o/

One of the few games I happily spent some money on. However I don't really recommend doing the same thing for new players. But let me explain.



I have no clue when did I get hooked into the game. Probably I saw someone streaming the game and decided to try it out. It was free to download, it was in alpha and it was quite fun. A few skilled players taught me the most important moves and tricks and I slowly figured out how these things work. And then I got a Closed beta key for free and after that, we're here.

I knew what awaited me when I bought the game. No risk for me (aside from the usual it's a dead game *hurr durr* waste of money"). I enjoy it because I know what I am

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have always been a fan of team sports, especially those that involve advancing an object to an opposing goal, like football, basketball, and hockey.  There are constant individual moves and coordinated team strategies going on that make each sport beautiful.  Any amazing effort or foolish mistake can mean success or failure.  This is Supraball.

Supraball can be enjoyed on a casual level, but competitive Supraball really shines.  Your teammates are counting on you.  Your heart is pounding; your adrenaline flowing.  I have never experienced this from any other video game.

The game is in early access.  I look forward to more features, and improved polish.  The gameplay is great, but it still needs features like instant replay to be a great full release.

Regardless, I've had years of fun playing Supraball and it's predecessor, Deathball.  It's a great game and it has huge potential.  It gives lazy, fat gamers like me the same feeling I'm sure professional athletes get.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The only negative thing I have to say about Supraball is the fact that it's SO GOOD that it has made almost every other game seem boring and mundane to me. I've played this game since August of 2014 and have never experienced a dull moment. If you are into competitive games then Supraball is a must. The amount of teamwork and the infinite amount of strategies you can come up with has made this game an all time favorite for me. It's a great game for both casual and competitive players with some of the most complex and unique game mechanics in any game i've ever played. Playing this game is like entering a time machine. 5 hours feel like 30 minutes and each game plays out differently from the next. Supraball also has a very high skill cap and incredible e-sport potential. I'm telling you guys, this game is a gem and there is no other game like it.

10/10 would recommend
voteText: 10 of 15 people (67%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Early Access Review

tldr I love this game. It's my favorite game/experience in all my years of playing games.

It's easy to learn, but impossible to master. There are no advantages for one player over another in this game. Everyone runs the same speed, jumps the same height, etc. You are in complete control of your character; therefore, the opportunity to be great is in your hands. This is the only video game I've ever played that makes me feel like I used to feel as an athlete. Other games have you controlling a character, but in this game, you are the character. Your play on the pitch is a vehicle for self-expression. If you want to outsmart your opponents, bully your opponents, be a playmaker, break ankles, or be the glue that holds a team together, you can do it.

All that being said, this is a game in which one player cannot dominate the game without a team. Teamwork is arguably the most important factor in the game. The teamwork element is another area in which a group of people can express themselves in the game. Just as one player can play a certain style that is all their own, teams have their own styles and strategies that distinguish themselves from each other. There are many different strategies that are equally valid.

This game has an individual and team skillcap that hasn't been reached yet. I can't wait to see what all you new players bring to the game I've loved for so long. The only limit is your creativity and your willingness to work at the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pros:
- Innovative first person sports game
- Soccer + Portal = this game
- Mostly friendly community
- Well optimized, runs on everything from a toaster to battlestation
- Easy to learn and play

Cons:
- Unbalanced teams
- Games where a team is losing would result in half that team quitting/leaving the game
- Not enough people playing it

This game is one of a kind and very fun to play. Despite the few cons I noticed, it is well worth a purchase. Could use some more players however, it's hard finding a full server as of 05/03/16

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you like games that are heavily dependent upon team play and high skill then Supraball is for you. However, as a beginner you may struggle for a bit since currently the game doesn‚Äôt include any tutorials or tips for newbie players. The community is quite friendly but nobody is going to teach you how to play so you will find yourself danced around, juked and generally outplayed as there is no ranking system yet and you are getting matched up against good players. They wont allow you to possession of the ball nor will you be able to catch it just running around. It‚Äôs not a very hard game to understand but I found it really hard to catch up at the beginning. The game itself seemed pretty fun and enjoyable even though I was running around without the ball most of the time. It‚Äôs in early access and has some bugs and a lot to improve upon like any other game but it definitely has a future. It can be filled with a lot of content.

PROS: Team play ‚Äì (the game is so far custom server based eligible to play 3v3 and 5v5)

Able to play with or without friends ‚Äì (you can invite them in 3v3 or 5v5 lobbies provided by the game itself ‚Äì I think you have to purchase ownership)

Smooth, fast and enjoyable ‚Äì (I found it really hard to get bored of this game even though I couldn‚Äôt catch up to the players that I got matched up with and yet I still find it enjoyable)

Community ‚Äì (so far I haven‚Äôt met anyone toxic flaming teammates for their mistakes, everyone seems to be friendly to each other, giving each other tips)

Future ‚Äì (the game has a lot to improve but it has the potential to evolve into something bigger. I can see a lot of features which can be added in my mind and so it is up to the developers to where they drive it to).
CONS: Tutorials ‚Äì (the game doesn‚Äôt have any tutorials or tips for beginners yet so it is hard to catch up for a new player against decent players who are usually premade and only pass to each other so you can become frustrated and feel useless)

Minor in game bugs ‚Äì (encountered only once with players getting stuck into each other)

Problems with video settings ‚Äì (I have encountered this a couple of times ‚Äì it doesn‚Äôt save the options and settings you change and resets to default when you reset the app)

Ranking ‚Äì (currently there is no ranking system which defines the skill group of players and separates them from each other to make the game more fair which means you might get matched up with higher ranking players and that probably wont end well for you)

This review is part of the Steamified[www.steamified.com] Community Reviews. I received this game for free thanks to Steamified and the developer. If you'd like to contribute your own reviews check out our Steam Group.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have been playing this game for 2 years since it has been in development, and I still look forward to spending hours playing after I get home from work. I have made some awesome friends, and some great memories. I have played in tournaments, ranked matches, and just messed around on a public server. All 3 totally different experiences with this game, and all equally enjoyable. Some matches end with my palms sweaty, my heart pacing, and my armpits soaked. Nothing I have ever played before has matched this intensity. This game can be really fast if you have the right group of experienced players. If you love sports, and are competitive in nature, this game is for you.

You have the ability to create teams, particiapte in tournaments, build up your rank and stats, and become a legendary goalie, defender, or midfielder that others will look up to. There's just so much to say about this game, that I can't even begin to explain it.  If you're interested in the least bit, take a chance on this game, I highly doubt that you will regret it.

I hope to see you on the pitch!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

-##-
Disclaimer:
I started playing Supraball 2013 and was part of the closed testing enviroment.
-##-

Supraball is a First-Person-Soccer game. It rewards fast paced teamoriented plays. It reminds me a little of Valves majorly underappriciated game Ricochet where movement and precision are key to a high level play. This can be frustrating for new players as the introduction and succes are depending on utilisation of creative and advance mechanics.
The visuals are simple yet pleasing and that results in a low hardware demand. A PC as strong as a PS4 should run it on medium settings.

Pros:
-Simple yet pleasing visuals
-Solid game mechanics
-Teamwork decides victory
-Rewarding and broad learning curve
-addictive for fooball/soccer lovers
-Not demanding towards Hardware

Cons:
-Not intuitive configuration of controls (new players should configure during practice alone [May.2016] as the launcher is still buggy)
-Sound Options are lacking
-Minor bugs in the launcher
-Launcher still needs a major overhaul
-Price and content not matching

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI am new to the game, and only 4 hours in as of this review. I get absolutely spanked most games, but I don't rage quit. Instead I strive to be better, so that I can be the spanker someday. Obviously there are veterans on here that have played much longer than most people, so expect to get tag teamed by gorillas every now and then until you hone your skills in a practice server. Don't be salty about losing, because you will adapt overtime and become a more adept player. You have to work as a team, and you have to have fast reflexes. The movement is like that of Unreal Tournament, so 12 year olds be damned. You can strafe dash left and right, and you can quad jump in the air, which is incredibly useful in avoiding a nice kick to the face. You can put a backspin, front spin, or a side spin on the ball, which confuses even the most hardened gods sometimes. Passing is easy too, but it's also very easy to intercept as well, so git gud. All in all, it's a great game with some relation to Rocket League, but don't call it a Rocket League rip off, because this came out before it. See you on the field fam.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

All the time I spent playing this game it was always fun but never the same.
In the beginning it's messing around on the pitch, learning controls, scoring your first goals, catch some balls as a keeper.
Then it's like learning volleys and improving precision, then getting better reflexes in goal.
Then a deep dive into teamplay and tactics, forming a team with friends and playing matches against other teams.
Then it's becoming creative and using the means you have to create ever new plays, juke defenders and keepers.
Then it's participating in a community league and getting to the top of the ladder.
Then it's winning a close yet so important game by your hands last second.
Lastly it's being carried away in ecstasy.

No regrets, perfect 5/7!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Aesthetically weak and uninspired, unoptimized, stagnant, feature-starved. These are just a few descriptors that I feel accurately represent the state of Supraball.

When buying a new game, I am often curious as to what creative energy went into bringing it to fruition. Supraball is a downgrade from the original mod in terms of art direction. This being the case primarily because Deathball used UT2K4 assets. Deathball had hundreds of user-created maps, a plethora of player models, replays, pausing, and in-game ready system, a more sophisticated kickoff system, better in-game stat tracking, and more gameplay variety. A UT2K4 mod, that had been in development for two years, had far more going on for it feature-wise than a standalone game that has, according to the dev team, been ‚Äúin the works‚Äù for four years. Being a programmer, I understand the challenges behind creating something like this. However, the dev team chose to price the game at $20. Rocket League also costs $20. Rocket League is far ahead of Supraball in almost every area one could think of, and the dev team has invited this comparison via their pricing decision.

Gameplay-wise, Supraball is nearly the perfect type of game for me. That I cannot recommend it to most gamers should be a red flag. If you put in the time, a high-level game of Supraball can be more interesting and enjoyable than perhaps any other game I‚Äôve played. It‚Äôs that you have to look past the poor art direction, underdeveloped visuals, missing features, nonsensical rank and lobby system, and the very steep learning curve (assuming you want to play in the higher-level games, which is where Supraball becomes far more interesting). In the hands of the right dev team, this type of game could be very successful, as you‚Äôve seen with something like Rocket League. The Rocket League dev team listens to their community, has been a lot of creative energy into their game, and seems to generally ‚Äúget it‚Äù. I cannot say the same for Supraball‚Äôs dev team. If you‚Äôre looking for something similar to Rocket League in concept, that gives you more control over what‚Äôs going on, and has, in my opinion, superior overall gameplay, buy Supraball. Just know that there are several glaring things that you must overlook, and I don‚Äôt feel that the vast majority of players are willing to or should have to. If you‚Äôre buying this game based on an expectation that it will continue to evolve, don‚Äôt. If the game were priced under $10 USD, I feel it would be easier for me to recommend. At $20‚Ä¶ No.

The low population is impossible to deal with.

If you're in the NA, you either get destroyed on EU servers because your latency makes it impossible to do basic ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, like catch the ball or you have deal with the trolls that are the NA player-base...

I have no hope for this game's future at all.  It's like new players were an after-thought.

Don't waste your time.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game might be fun if it was geared more toward casual gamers, but it's really not like that. The game is overrun with people that ruin the experience for all newcomers. Also, it looks horrible and plays pretty bad. Kinda slow paced, very unremarkable. I was thinking similar to rocket league... not even close. NOT WORTH $15... maybe worth $4.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

EDIT: One of the developers added me on Steam to get some input from me and he was actually quite a nice guy. He took on board my thoughts, put in a bug request from an issue I had and really professional the whole time. I will probably try the game again on a free weekend in the future.

I'm not really sure how this game has been in development since 2012. The launcher is horrible, the graphics could be beaten by a flash game and it is all basically an eyesore.

I know a lot of people really seem to like the game but I just can't understand the hype. The game was boring, felt clunky and didn't feel worth the ¬£11 or so I paid for it.

I know somebody is going to say Oh
date: but it's in Early Access!!1!".. It's been in development for 4 years
